author.bio:
Faith, Hope, and Love is the path to Life, Liberty, and Happiness.

There is no justification for any human authority.
author.bio_html:
Faith, Hope, and Love is the path to Life, Liberty, and Happiness.

There is no justification for any human authority.

body:
The Kingdom of God is where you are truly a citizen - a Christian makes that choice to become apart of the kingdom.  You cannot do this with earthly governments; you will be subjugated.

Why have loyalty to an entity and activity that throws your generation into meaningless wars, allows you to be further subjugated by the financial system by means of debt and usury, taxes you incessantly, tells you you can't do anything without proper licensing, that sells you out to oppressive foreign interests, de-values your savings by planned inflation,  enforces lockdowns, Kills your babies, etc...

What does your earthly government do right now that makes you want to participate in what it is doing?  Do you suppose it upholds Christian values?  Where? When has this ever been done?

Do you suppose your government - specifically the USA - was founded on Christianity?  Where in the constitution does it mention anything about it?

Why do you vote?  To be an accomplice in what ever pyschopath politician enacts and enforces?  Do you enjoy imposing your will on others?

A Christian only serves one and that is God.  You cannot serve both your government and God.

Why do you vote? To be an accomplice in what ever pyschopath politician enacts and enforces? Do you enjoy imposing your will on others?

body:
I grew up with my father watching Bill O'Reilly.  2 years ago, after the social violence on Facebook revolving around Trump, my father finally arrived at the conclusion- "one cannot serve two masters."  He came to realize that his faith overruled all politics and he stopped caring.  His life improved dramatically.  He made his life about his wife, his kids, his grandkids and his church and he is now finally happy.  He listened to Rush Limbaugh while driving for 20 years.  Now he looks out the window and "wonders at God's creation."

If you're a Christian, you CAN'T engage in politics.  You were promised persecution.  The Bible actually promises that the world will fall and Christians will be defeated in the battle for the physical realm but that the kingdom of heaven will smite those who conquered the world.  "The wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ."

Christians are promised pain and defeat.  Their faith is what carries them through to promises that exceed this world.  I wish I was one.

body:
Christ said to render to Ceasar what is his. Rebellion isn't always the answer. If you want a functional society where people can exchange goods and food and settle their disputes in private instead of killing eachother in the street some form of government will inevitably arise, even if it's a small group of people, politics and power struggles will arise. 

The mass of humanity will always be born into these systems even if our opinion of how things should be is more enlightened. Understanding this is a form of forgiveness.

body: I would mostly agree with that, but it’s somewhat relative. I think the main contingent being that the right to worship God and obey Him supersedes any mortal authority and thus grounds for an alternate government. I wouldn’t say it super cut and dry, there’s different scenarios and wisdom in the Bible that can lead to different interpretations. But I think the interpretation should be logically consistent with wholistic theology rather than a verse or two. But interestingly God’s government will be a kingdom. And God rules with both spiritual beings as partners and humans.

body:
The Kingdom of God in Earth was the Islamic caliphate. Christianity today is paramount to idolatry of Jesus. Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God, and then the entirety of the Roman world bought it.

You should never ascribe a partner to God. There is no entity within or without the creation that is even similar to Him. Jesus was a man who walked in the marketplace and bought groceries just like you and I. God gave him miracles to lead the people, and correct their opinion of God, and to warn them about the antichrist. How can you insult God by saying he died or became a man? That's the most nonsensical gibberish you can utter.

Jesus was the Messiah and a Prophet, not some form of God Himself.

Here is a much more thorough explanation of this more convincing argument:

https://youtube.com/watch?v=fY1ZKWF-_wI

Abandon the worship of a man, and stop saying that the eternal self sufficient, unfathomable creator of the universe killed Himself in the form of Jesus. It does not stand up to rational logic even  slightly.

Your texts have been halfway forged and rewritten by Paul (who even claimed divine revelation) and the like, and don't exist in their original aramaic.

This is the entire reason Mohamed, sallahu alayhi wasalam, was sent with the exact same message as Christ, except to the entirety of Mankind, and not to the Jews among the Romans.

body:
>Well not when you strawman it like that, sure. The death and resurrection of Christ as a way for God to sever karmic slavery between humans and the world they are born into (which envelops them in sin and separation) does actually make sense.

Please explain to me why the omnipotent creator of the universe has to go through some elaborate process to achieve something like forgiving humanity for their sins. He simply says "be" and it is.

>Your views are not only understandable but are well known and have already been addressed many times over thousands of years.

And the Christian concensus seems to stray further and further from rational logic each century. 

Why does Jesus say ver batim in Hebrew translated (one time from Aramaic) that "Your God is eschad". This is identical in etymology to the word "ahad" in Arabic, which means ABSOLUTELY SINGULAR. How do people see that Jesus uttered this about the one true God, and then make lies about a trinity? God cannot be eschad (literally singular) and part of a triplet. Literally nonsensical.

I urge you to read the Quran. It calls you, the Christian scholar, nothing but wise. It says you have renounced the world, and when you hear the Quran (as the Arabic Christians did) and contemplate it that you will weep. 

>Verily, you will find the strongest among men in enmity to the believers (Muslims) the Jews and those who are Al-Mushrikun (see V. 2:105), and you will find the nearest in love to the believers (Muslims) those who say: "We are Christians." That is because amongst them are priests and monks, and they are not proud.

>And when they hear what has been sent down to the Messenger, you see their eyes overflow with tears for what they recognize of the Truth. They say, "Our Lord, we believe; so write us down among the witnesses.

https://quran.com/5/82-83

So if you think our original text from Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) is a fraud, why don't you actually read it.

body:
This goes against the fundamental Christian belief of salvation and it's what makes Christianity different from all other religions, making it more convincing that Christ is the only way to heaven. 

The difference between Christianity and other religions is that in every other religion, you get salvation by coming closer to God(/enlightenment) by doing good deeds or practice in accord with the religion which will determine your salvation. 

In Christianity though, after many failed attempts of God to make man's heart obey trough law, God came to man instead as an act of grace. God came into the flesh and got Jesus condemnded for man's sins so that we can effectively use the Spirit of Jesus for salvation and be clear in Him as He got the sins already got condemned. Christ makes us, severely flawed and fallen people, perfect. 

Thus the only way to heaven as sinful fallen people is by putting all our faith in Christ and walking in His spirit. Since He is someone God sent as an act of immense grace for the ever sinful fallen man.

body:
>In Christianity though, after many failed attempts of God to make man's heart obey trough law, God came to man instead as an act of grace. God came into the flesh and got Jesus condemnded for man's sins so that we can effectively use the Spirit of Jesus for salvation and be clear in Him as He got the sins already got condemned. Christ makes us, severely flawed and fallen people, perfect.

>God came into the flesh

This statement doesn't make physical sense. How can the creator of the universe (who resides "above" it, on a "throne" the details of which we cannot imagine) somehow become some mortal creation?

That's just polytheism with a bunch of sugar on top of it. Jesus is not God. That is paganism. Pharoah called himself God, but Jesus did not. And yet you believe that a man who did not call himself God was God, part of him, or his begotten (literally implying that God had copus) son. These are all forms of paganism, and not the true doctrine of Christ, which was pure monotheism: God is king, and every other entity ever created (including Jesus) is and always will exist in a state of complete slavehood to his predestined will.

Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent because early Christians disagreed on Christ's fate, decided to abandon the teachings of Christ, and burned all of their religious documents at Nicea. 

>The difference between Christianity and other religions is that in every other religion, you get salvation by coming closer to God(/enlightenment) by doing good deeds or practice in accord with the religion which will determine your salvation.

This is because most religions, including those of the Torah, Bhagavad Gita, Avesta, and were all originally sent as revelation to Prophets. Islam is the name for a religion that is older than Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam). It is the name in Arabic of acceptance of the law and authority of God alone. 

If you want to practice the original religion of Jesus, as he practiced it, you need to look at Islam. How do you think Jesus prayed? He prostrated like Muslims do. Go look up how Jesus prayed in the garden even according to Christian sources.

This is the same way that Arjun (another likely Prophet) prayed to Krishna (the Indian word for the One True God - which is now part of their paganism).

It is the way that Muslims were taught to pray to the One True God. 

Christianity is close to the truth. They are the closest in friendship to the Muslims, but they have a severe misunderstanding about the nature of the Messiah. This is basically the entire reason that Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent revelation (because the religion of Jesus was perverted at Nicea - when Arius convinced the councilmen that Jesus was God or part of a trinity).

Nonetheless, I support your right to argue/defend your stance (even in the middle of Saudi Arabia - as this is what the Prophet sallahu alayhi wasalam allowed), and I wish you and your family a lovely celebration of Christ the Messiah (alayhi salam) at this time of year even if we disagree about his nature (part of God or not). I hope that you might refrain from mocking our Prophet Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) before you have learned what he taught in full (or maybe even read the Quran he brought), as we will never in a trillion billion years mock the Messiah. No Muslim on Earth who has received an ounce of education in their own religion will mock Christ (alayhi salam - upon him be peace).

body:
It's all still 1 God. God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature. This is no polytheism or paganism, nor idolatry. How I see it, this is how idolatry got defeated, since it's easy really to treat a vague concept of God as an idol. Then it won't be any different from worshipping a pagan god, when you see it as an idol. Trough Jesus and the Holy Spirit, God is shown to be alive, not an idol. He is still 1 and King and that very same King was in Jesus, and that very same King is in the Holy Spirit which can be received in me and you and every human. In a sense, Jesus wasn't special, everyone can become like Jesus when they have faith in Him and accept God (aka the Holy Spirit) in them. 

God is still higher dimensional and incomprehensible for us humans to grasp, but He is alive and always in us. Our very conciousness depends on His light. This doesn't conflict with the Jesus story of how He went into the flesh to make it possible for us to become a vessel for God. Otherwise only the intellectuals and the theologians would perhaps have a better understanding of God (which probably won't even help their faith) while all laymen practiced the equivalent of idolatry.

I realize you may consider Jesus to be an idol, but it's His teachings and the mindset that comes along with it that are to be worshipped as Godly, not an idol with the name Jesus. In a sense you can't treat Jesus as an idol or seperate god if you know about Him because of his great humility in his teachings, you are lead to God when you try to.

I'll respect you as a Muslim, I do not know much about your faith but plan on learning more about it. I have friends and family who are Muslim. I won't be moved in my faith but you still increased my respect. It's only when violence (and thus freedom) is on the line that I will take a stand, otherwise Christians are to be pacifist either way. 

Edit: note that I really don't mind on whether or not people mock Christ. I encounter people who do that very frequently and even people in my own household do. I expect it, I used to do it myself not too long ago. My respect for muslims would increase a lot if they are shown to have the same humility or pacifist mentality toward criticism of their beliefs and prophets.

parent.body:
>In Christianity though, after many failed attempts of God to make man's heart obey trough law, God came to man instead as an act of grace. God came into the flesh and got Jesus condemnded for man's sins so that we can effectively use the Spirit of Jesus for salvation and be clear in Him as He got the sins already got condemned. Christ makes us, severely flawed and fallen people, perfect.

>God came into the flesh

This statement doesn't make physical sense. How can the creator of the universe (who resides "above" it, on a "throne" the details of which we cannot imagine) somehow become some mortal creation?

That's just polytheism with a bunch of sugar on top of it. Jesus is not God. That is paganism. Pharoah called himself God, but Jesus did not. And yet you believe that a man who did not call himself God was God, part of him, or his begotten (literally implying that God had copus) son. These are all forms of paganism, and not the true doctrine of Christ, which was pure monotheism: God is king, and every other entity ever created (including Jesus) is and always will exist in a state of complete slavehood to his predestined will.

Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent because early Christians disagreed on Christ's fate, decided to abandon the teachings of Christ, and burned all of their religious documents at Nicea. 

>The difference between Christianity and other religions is that in every other religion, you get salvation by coming closer to God(/enlightenment) by doing good deeds or practice in accord with the religion which will determine your salvation.

This is because most religions, including those of the Torah, Bhagavad Gita, Avesta, and were all originally sent as revelation to Prophets. Islam is the name for a religion that is older than Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam). It is the name in Arabic of acceptance of the law and authority of God alone. 

If you want to practice the original religion of Jesus, as he practiced it, you need to look at Islam. How do you think Jesus prayed? He prostrated like Muslims do. Go look up how Jesus prayed in the garden even according to Christian sources.

This is the same way that Arjun (another likely Prophet) prayed to Krishna (the Indian word for the One True God - which is now part of their paganism).

It is the way that Muslims were taught to pray to the One True God. 

Christianity is close to the truth. They are the closest in friendship to the Muslims, but they have a severe misunderstanding about the nature of the Messiah. This is basically the entire reason that Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent revelation (because the religion of Jesus was perverted at Nicea - when Arius convinced the councilmen that Jesus was God or part of a trinity).

Nonetheless, I support your right to argue/defend your stance (even in the middle of Saudi Arabia - as this is what the Prophet sallahu alayhi wasalam allowed), and I wish you and your family a lovely celebration of Christ the Messiah (alayhi salam) at this time of year even if we disagree about his nature (part of God or not). I hope that you might refrain from mocking our Prophet Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) before you have learned what he taught in full (or maybe even read the Quran he brought), as we will never in a trillion billion years mock the Messiah. No Muslim on Earth who has received an ounce of education in their own religion will mock Christ (alayhi salam - upon him be peace).

body:
>God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature.

God, the immortal unborn undying sustainer of all existence for eternity did not become a mortal, human being and allow some Romans to kill Him. God can forgive your sins immediately or not. God can do whatever he pleases instantly. He does not need to become Jesus and die to forgive your sins.
body_html:
God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature.

God, the immortal unborn undying sustainer of all existence for eternity did not become a mortal, human being and allow some Romans to kill Him. God can forgive your sins immediately or not. God can do whatever he pleases instantly. He does not need to become Jesus and die to forgive your sins.

parent.body:
It's all still 1 God. God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature. This is no polytheism or paganism, nor idolatry. How I see it, this is how idolatry got defeated, since it's easy really to treat a vague concept of God as an idol. Then it won't be any different from worshipping a pagan god, when you see it as an idol. Trough Jesus and the Holy Spirit, God is shown to be alive, not an idol. He is still 1 and King and that very same King was in Jesus, and that very same King is in the Holy Spirit which can be received in me and you and every human. In a sense, Jesus wasn't special, everyone can become like Jesus when they have faith in Him and accept God (aka the Holy Spirit) in them. 

God is still higher dimensional and incomprehensible for us humans to grasp, but He is alive and always in us. Our very conciousness depends on His light. This doesn't conflict with the Jesus story of how He went into the flesh to make it possible for us to become a vessel for God. Otherwise only the intellectuals and the theologians would perhaps have a better understanding of God (which probably won't even help their faith) while all laymen practiced the equivalent of idolatry.

I realize you may consider Jesus to be an idol, but it's His teachings and the mindset that comes along with it that are to be worshipped as Godly, not an idol with the name Jesus. In a sense you can't treat Jesus as an idol or seperate god if you know about Him because of his great humility in his teachings, you are lead to God when you try to.

I'll respect you as a Muslim, I do not know much about your faith but plan on learning more about it. I have friends and family who are Muslim. I won't be moved in my faith but you still increased my respect. It's only when violence (and thus freedom) is on the line that I will take a stand, otherwise Christians are to be pacifist either way. 

Edit: note that I really don't mind on whether or not people mock Christ. I encounter people who do that very frequently and even people in my own household do. I expect it, I used to do it myself not too long ago. My respect for muslims would increase a lot if they are shown to have the same humility or pacifist mentality toward criticism of their beliefs and prophets.

body: That's what makes it so beautiful. God didn't need to do any of it. We as humans are fallen sinful people and all deserve hell. It was an act of immense grace from God out of His love for us, something we are to cherish with our whole being. That's why those who don't acknowledge this act of immense grace can't be saved.  He made the path straight to Him. He can do what He pleases and as He wished He sent Jesus as our savior while still respecting our free will (and thus our capacity to love). He could have prevented Christ's death but as He so often said, it was predetermined to happen as to fulfill scripture and to gain the support base and faith and saving intended with the ressurection.

body:
>God didn't need to do any of it.

He did not need to and he did not become a man. That's very very roughly (almost inappropriate analogy) like saying the programmer crawled inside of the computer code that he made (it is just not logical to say). God and the creation are mutually exclusive. Saying that God becomes part of the creation is paganism (having a false God) because at that point your view of God is marred. 

>He could have prevented Christ's death

Muslims believe that God did, and that Jesus (alayhi salam) ascended to heaven immediately as a miracle of God, and that Jesus (alayhi salam) will be returning to slay the antichrist (the jew with one eye that all the freemasons and satanists worship). Jesus (alayhi salam) never died. He is in heaven now and will be returning soon. Almost all of the Prophecies of Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) for Jesus' returning have been fulfilled.

parent.body:
I grew up with my father watching Bill O'Reilly.  2 years ago, after the social violence on Facebook revolving around Trump, my father finally arrived at the conclusion- "one cannot serve two masters."  He came to realize that his faith overruled all politics and he stopped caring.  His life improved dramatically.  He made his life about his wife, his kids, his grandkids and his church and he is now finally happy.  He listened to Rush Limbaugh while driving for 20 years.  Now he looks out the window and "wonders at God's creation."

body:
That's complete nonsense, and you don't have a clue what you're talking about, like all Evangelicals. First off, sola fideism wasn't even invented until the 16th century, before that the entirety of Christianity was Cathodoxy. Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to  accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

Thirdly, not even Paul promised salvation to idolaters, on the contrary. And it wasn't his to promise anyway. God isn't man, God isn't Jesus, and there's only one God. What you worship and serve is a satanic abomination. And there's no salvation in idolatry.

This goes against the fundamental Christian belief of salvation and it's what makes Christianity different from all other religions, making it more convincing that Christ is the only way to heaven. 

The difference between Christianity and other religions is that in every other religion, you get salvation by coming closer to God(/enlightenment) by doing good deeds or practice in accord with the religion which will determine your salvation. 

In Christianity though, after many failed attempts of God to make man's heart obey trough law, God came to man instead as an act of grace. God came into the flesh and got Jesus condemnded for man's sins so that we can effectively use the Spirit of Jesus for salvation and be clear in Him as He got the sins already got condemned. Christ makes us, severely flawed and fallen people, perfect. 

Thus the only way to heaven as sinful fallen people is by putting all our faith in Christ and walking in His spirit. Since He is someone God sent as an act of immense grace for the ever sinful fallen man.

parent.body:
It's all still 1 God. God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature. This is no polytheism or paganism, nor idolatry. How I see it, this is how idolatry got defeated, since it's easy really to treat a vague concept of God as an idol. Then it won't be any different from worshipping a pagan god, when you see it as an idol. Trough Jesus and the Holy Spirit, God is shown to be alive, not an idol. He is still 1 and King and that very same King was in Jesus, and that very same King is in the Holy Spirit which can be received in me and you and every human. In a sense, Jesus wasn't special, everyone can become like Jesus when they have faith in Him and accept God (aka the Holy Spirit) in them. 

God is still higher dimensional and incomprehensible for us humans to grasp, but He is alive and always in us. Our very conciousness depends on His light. This doesn't conflict with the Jesus story of how He went into the flesh to make it possible for us to become a vessel for God. Otherwise only the intellectuals and the theologians would perhaps have a better understanding of God (which probably won't even help their faith) while all laymen practiced the equivalent of idolatry.

I realize you may consider Jesus to be an idol, but it's His teachings and the mindset that comes along with it that are to be worshipped as Godly, not an idol with the name Jesus. In a sense you can't treat Jesus as an idol or seperate god if you know about Him because of his great humility in his teachings, you are lead to God when you try to.

I'll respect you as a Muslim, I do not know much about your faith but plan on learning more about it. I have friends and family who are Muslim. I won't be moved in my faith but you still increased my respect. It's only when violence (and thus freedom) is on the line that I will take a stand, otherwise Christians are to be pacifist either way. 

Edit: note that I really don't mind on whether or not people mock Christ. I encounter people who do that very frequently and even people in my own household do. I expect it, I used to do it myself not too long ago. My respect for muslims would increase a lot if they are shown to have the same humility or pacifist mentality toward criticism of their beliefs and prophets.

body:
>Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God

That's not correct. The NT calls Jesus the son of God, and the most you could ever extrapolate from it is Arianism. Arius correctly reasoned (whether you believe the NT or not) that a son, Jesus, per definition had to have a beginning, and that Jesus was pre-existing, but subordinate to God. The Church, Nicea and the Alexandrian fraction wouldn't have that though, which is why they promoted Jesus co-equal to God, declared His sonship to the eternal (a contradiction obviously), and decided that he was only relationally or economically subordinate, not ontologically.
body_html:

The Church, Nicea and the Alexandrian fraction wouldn't have that though, which is why they promoted Jesus co-equal to God, declared His sonship to the eternal (a contradiction obviously), and decided that he was only relationally or economically subordinate, not ontologically.

The Kingdom of God in Earth was the Islamic caliphate. Christianity today is paramount to idolatry of Jesus. Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God, and then the entirety of the Roman world bought it.

You should never ascribe a partner to God. There is no entity within or without the creation that is even similar to Him. Jesus was a man who walked in the marketplace and bought groceries just like you and I. God gave him miracles to lead the people, and correct their opinion of God, and to warn them about the antichrist. How can you insult God by saying he died or became a man? That's the most nonsensical gibberish you can utter.

Jesus was the Messiah and a Prophet, not some form of God Himself.

Here is a much more thorough explanation of this more convincing argument:

https://youtube.com/watch?v=fY1ZKWF-_wI

Abandon the worship of a man, and stop saying that the eternal self sufficient, unfathomable creator of the universe killed Himself in the form of Jesus. It does not stand up to rational logic even  slightly.

Your texts have been halfway forged and rewritten by Paul (who even claimed divine revelation) and the like, and don't exist in their original aramaic.

This is the entire reason Mohamed, sallahu alayhi wasalam, was sent with the exact same message as Christ, except to the entirety of Mankind, and not to the Jews among the Romans.

body:
Romans 1:18-22

For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who suppress the truth in unrighteousness, because what may be known of God is manifest in them, for God has shown it to them. For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead, so that they are without excuse, because, although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became futile in their thoughts, and their foolish hearts were darkened. **Professing to be wise, they became fools.**

body:
>but I would say trinitarianism makes the most sense based on my reading of Scripture

Your reading of scripture is wrong then, because the most you could ever extrapolate from any Christian canon is Arianism. And the satanic triad-idol is based on the Nicene-Constantinopolitan Creed alone. 

>I read the King James Bible and I couldn't recite the history of how it was canonized to you. 

Ok. The KJV is an Anglican translation, by-default based on the Catholic canon, and Jerome's Vulgate. The fact remains; 2 Tim. 3:16 isn't self-referential, the Bible canons as compiled and canonized doesn't claim themselves to be God's word and you don't even have a foundation of canonicity. And like I said, I'm a servant of God, and follower of no man.

body:
I love you too much not to pray for you ❤

Christ alone is the way to the Father. (John 14:6-7)

John 1

In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was in the beginning with God. All things were made through Him, and without Him nothing was made that was made...He was in the world, and the world was made through Him, and the world did not know Him. He came to His own, and His own did not receive Him. But as many as received Him, to them He gave the right to become children of God, to those who believe in His name: who were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God. And the Word became flesh and dwelt among us, and we beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth.

Colossians 1:15-17

He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation. For by Him all things were created that are in heaven and that are on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or principalities or powers. All things were created through Him and for Him. And He is before all things, and in Him all things consist.

body:
You don't know me, you don't love me, I don't love you, and you wouldn't even know which God to pray to. Can you even explain why there's no definite article when the logos is called theos in John's prologue, polytheist? Can you explain, say, John 17:3? Of course you can't. 

Can you even decide if Jesus is God's son or God #2? Of course you can't you can't even decide if you're a trinitarian or not. And according to your own scripture there won't be any trinitarians or deity of Jesus worshippers in the kingdom anyway (Rev. 1:6, 3:12). Idolaters have their portion in the lake of fire. 

Your faith is a satanic abomination, and according to James 2:19, your is below even the faith of literal demons. If there ever will be a Whore of Babylon it's Christianity, and if there ever will be a Mark of the Beast, it's the one Christians have already willingly taken.

body:
Denominations, movements, .. whatever you want to call it. You get my point.

I thought you responded to the latest comment which was further in the thread:

https://ruqqus.com/+ChristianAnarchy/post/5ty0/why-do-christians-have-any-loyalty/lcqr

>He can do what He pleases and as He wished He sent Jesus as our savior while still respecting our free will

>God can can do as He wishes, thus also become part of the creation. He is truly all powerful and all encompassing. Christ still prayed to God as His son, He didn't claim to represent the whole of God's essence. Christ is God incarnate

>As you are in Christ, Christ is in God

It's all still 1 God. Never did I particularly suggest modalism though. Here is what you're suspicious of probably but if you read it carefully you understand what is meant:

>It's all still 1 God. God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature. This is no polytheism or paganism, nor idolatry.

>He is still 1 and King and that very same King was in Jesus, and that very same King is in the Holy Spirit which can be received in me and you and every human. In a sense, **Jesus wasn't special, everyone can become like Jesus when they have faith in Him and accept God (aka the Holy Spirit) in them.**

Neither trinitarian or modalist would agree to being able to become God **the Father**, that would be pantheism or something. So yes even in the post you responded to it's evident if you ask me.

I wasn't aqcuainted with the word "modolism" but I guess it speaks for itself that it probably means opposite of trinity.

https://ruqqus.com/+ChristianAnarchy/post/5ty0/why-do-christians-have-any-loyalty/lcqr

He can do what He pleases and as He wished He sent Jesus as our savior while still respecting our free will

God can can do as He wishes, thus also become part of the creation. He is truly all powerful and all encompassing. Christ still prayed to God as His son, He didn't claim to represent the whole of God's essence. Christ is God incarnate

As you are in Christ, Christ is in God

It's all still 1 God. Never did I particularly suggest modalism though. Here is what you're suspicious of probably but if you read it carefully you understand what is meant:

It's all still 1 God. God coming into the flesh doesn't change God's nature. This is no polytheism or paganism, nor idolatry.

He is still 1 and King and that very same King was in Jesus, and that very same King is in the Holy Spirit which can be received in me and you and every human. In a sense, Jesus wasn't special, everyone can become like Jesus when they have faith in Him and accept God (aka the Holy Spirit) in them.

parent.body:
I grew up with my father watching Bill O'Reilly.  2 years ago, after the social violence on Facebook revolving around Trump, my father finally arrived at the conclusion- "one cannot serve two masters."  He came to realize that his faith overruled all politics and he stopped caring.  His life improved dramatically.  He made his life about his wife, his kids, his grandkids and his church and he is now finally happy.  He listened to Rush Limbaugh while driving for 20 years.  Now he looks out the window and "wonders at God's creation."

If you're a Christian, you CAN'T engage in politics.  You were promised persecution.  The Bible actually promises that the world will fall and Christians will be defeated in the battle for the physical realm but that the kingdom of heaven will smite those who conquered the world.  "The wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ."

Christians are promised pain and defeat.  Their faith is what carries them through to promises that exceed this world.  I wish I was one.

body:
> Abandon the worship of a man, and stop saying that the eternal self sufficient, unfathomable creator of the universe killed Himself in the form of Jesus. It does not stand up to rational logic even slightly.

Then how are we to be absolved?

> Your texts have been halfway forged and rewritten by Paul (who even claimed divine revelation) and the like, and don't exist in their original aramaic.

Paul was not the forger and there is zero evidence that most of the works were originally in aramaic (yes they probably spoke aramaic, but they wanted gentiles to be able to read it too, so they instead wrote in greek). In fact Paul's letters are by a long way the *most* tampered with; the gospels are still mostly intact in their original form as promised. Paul was a good man and a faithful defender of Christ.

The Kingdom of God in Earth was the Islamic caliphate. Christianity today is paramount to idolatry of Jesus. Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God, and then the entirety of the Roman world bought it.

You should never ascribe a partner to God. There is no entity within or without the creation that is even similar to Him. Jesus was a man who walked in the marketplace and bought groceries just like you and I. God gave him miracles to lead the people, and correct their opinion of God, and to warn them about the antichrist. How can you insult God by saying he died or became a man? That's the most nonsensical gibberish you can utter.

Jesus was the Messiah and a Prophet, not some form of God Himself.

Here is a much more thorough explanation of this more convincing argument:

https://youtube.com/watch?v=fY1ZKWF-_wI

Abandon the worship of a man, and stop saying that the eternal self sufficient, unfathomable creator of the universe killed Himself in the form of Jesus. It does not stand up to rational logic even  slightly.

Your texts have been halfway forged and rewritten by Paul (who even claimed divine revelation) and the like, and don't exist in their original aramaic.

This is the entire reason Mohamed, sallahu alayhi wasalam, was sent with the exact same message as Christ, except to the entirety of Mankind, and not to the Jews among the Romans.

body:
Now read Romans 2, where Paul responds to this passage with "You, therefore, have no excuse, you who pass judgment on someone else, for at whatever point you judge another, you are condemning yourself, because you who pass judgment do the same things. Now we know that God’s judgment against those who do such things is based on truth. So when you, a mere human being, pass judgment on them and yet do the same things, do you think you will escape God’s judgment?"

It then becomes clear that 18-32 is a self-righteous boast from the church in Rome which Paul is condemning, and rightfully so. Romans has many instances of back and forth dialogue, and he does it without warning his readers, because he is assuming that his recipient will recognize their own words the way someone on ruqqus would when someone replies to their comment. I find it funny how this is one of the most favorite passages of many Christians who love to boast and proclaim their piousness and yet it is exactly what Paul condemned.

Also I'm not sure what this has to do with scripture canon.

Romans 1:18-22

For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who suppress the truth in unrighteousness, because what may be known of God is manifest in them, for God has shown it to them. For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead, so that they are without excuse, because, although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became futile in their thoughts, and their foolish hearts were darkened. **Professing to be wise, they became fools.**

>In Christianity though, after many failed attempts of God to make man's heart obey trough law, God came to man instead as an act of grace. God came into the flesh and got Jesus condemnded for man's sins so that we can effectively use the Spirit of Jesus for salvation and be clear in Him as He got the sins already got condemned. Christ makes us, severely flawed and fallen people, perfect.

>God came into the flesh

This statement doesn't make physical sense. How can the creator of the universe (who resides "above" it, on a "throne" the details of which we cannot imagine) somehow become some mortal creation?

That's just polytheism with a bunch of sugar on top of it. Jesus is not God. That is paganism. Pharoah called himself God, but Jesus did not. And yet you believe that a man who did not call himself God was God, part of him, or his begotten (literally implying that God had copus) son. These are all forms of paganism, and not the true doctrine of Christ, which was pure monotheism: God is king, and every other entity ever created (including Jesus) is and always will exist in a state of complete slavehood to his predestined will.

Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent because early Christians disagreed on Christ's fate, decided to abandon the teachings of Christ, and burned all of their religious documents at Nicea. 

>The difference between Christianity and other religions is that in every other religion, you get salvation by coming closer to God(/enlightenment) by doing good deeds or practice in accord with the religion which will determine your salvation.

This is because most religions, including those of the Torah, Bhagavad Gita, Avesta, and were all originally sent as revelation to Prophets. Islam is the name for a religion that is older than Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam). It is the name in Arabic of acceptance of the law and authority of God alone. 

If you want to practice the original religion of Jesus, as he practiced it, you need to look at Islam. How do you think Jesus prayed? He prostrated like Muslims do. Go look up how Jesus prayed in the garden even according to Christian sources.

This is the same way that Arjun (another likely Prophet) prayed to Krishna (the Indian word for the One True God - which is now part of their paganism).

It is the way that Muslims were taught to pray to the One True God. 

Christianity is close to the truth. They are the closest in friendship to the Muslims, but they have a severe misunderstanding about the nature of the Messiah. This is basically the entire reason that Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent revelation (because the religion of Jesus was perverted at Nicea - when Arius convinced the councilmen that Jesus was God or part of a trinity).

Nonetheless, I support your right to argue/defend your stance (even in the middle of Saudi Arabia - as this is what the Prophet sallahu alayhi wasalam allowed), and I wish you and your family a lovely celebration of Christ the Messiah (alayhi salam) at this time of year even if we disagree about his nature (part of God or not). I hope that you might refrain from mocking our Prophet Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) before you have learned what he taught in full (or maybe even read the Quran he brought), as we will never in a trillion billion years mock the Messiah. No Muslim on Earth who has received an ounce of education in their own religion will mock Christ (alayhi salam - upon him be peace).

This is because most religions, including those of the Torah, Bhagavad Gita, Avesta, and were all originally sent as revelation to Prophets. If you want to practice the original religion of Jesus, as he practiced it, you need to look at Islam. How do you think Jesus prayed? He prostrated like Muslims do. Go look up how Jesus prayed in the garden even according to Christian sources.

This is the same way that Arjun (another likely Prophet) prayed to Krishna (the Indian word for the One True God - which is now part of their paganism).

It is the way that Muslims were taught to pray to the One True God.

Christianity is close to the truth. They are the closest in friendship to the Muslims, but they have a severe misunderstanding about the nature of the Messiah. This is basically the entire reason that Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) was sent revelation (because the religion of Jesus was perverted at Nicea - when Arius convinced the councilmen that Jesus was God or part of a trinity).

Nonetheless, I support your right to argue/defend your stance (even in the middle of Saudi Arabia - as this is what the Prophet sallahu alayhi wasalam allowed), and I wish you and your family a lovely celebration of Christ the Messiah (alayhi salam) at this time of year even if we disagree about his nature (part of God or not). I hope that you might refrain from mocking our Prophet Mohamed (sallahu alayhi wasalam) before you have learned what he taught in full (or maybe even read the Quran he brought), as we will never in a trillion billion years mock the Messiah. No Muslim on Earth who has received an ounce of education in their own religion will mock Christ (alayhi salam - upon him be peace).

> Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

What are you talking about? Paul in my opinion is 100% in line with Jesus. Also Jesus clearly taught faith and not works several times, most famously:

> To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector. I fast twice a week and give a tenth of all I get.’ But the tax collector stood at a distance. He would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’ I tell you that this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God. For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
body_html:
Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to accommodate to his new doctrines. To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. parent.body:
That's complete nonsense, and you don't have a clue what you're talking about, like all Evangelicals. First off, sola fideism wasn't even invented until the 16th century, before that the entirety of Christianity was Cathodoxy. Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to  accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

Thirdly, not even Paul promised salvation to idolaters, on the contrary. And it wasn't his to promise anyway. God isn't man, God isn't Jesus, and there's only one God. What you worship and serve is a satanic abomination. And there's no salvation in idolatry.

body: John calls God the word, and it also calls Jesus the word. I think we can put 2 and 2 together from that.
body_html: John calls God the word, and it also calls Jesus the word. I think we can put 2 and 2 together from that.

parent.body:
>Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God

That's not correct. The NT calls Jesus the son of God, and the most you could ever extrapolate from it is Arianism. Arius correctly reasoned (whether you believe the NT or not) that a son, Jesus, per definition had to have a beginning, and that Jesus was pre-existing, but subordinate to God. The Church, Nicea and the Alexandrian fraction wouldn't have that though, which is why they promoted Jesus co-equal to God, declared His sonship to the eternal (a contradiction obviously), and decided that he was only relationally or economically subordinate, not ontologically.

parent.body:
Now read Romans 2, where Paul responds to this passage with "You, therefore, have no excuse, you who pass judgment on someone else, for at whatever point you judge another, you are condemning yourself, because you who pass judgment do the same things. Now we know that God’s judgment against those who do such things is based on truth. So when you, a mere human being, pass judgment on them and yet do the same things, do you think you will escape God’s judgment?"

It then becomes clear that 18-32 is a self-righteous boast from the church in Rome which Paul is condemning, and rightfully so. Romans has many instances of back and forth dialogue, and he does it without warning his readers, because he is assuming that his recipient will recognize their own words the way someone on ruqqus would when someone replies to their comment. I find it funny how this is one of the most favorite passages of many Christians who love to boast and proclaim their piousness and yet it is exactly what Paul condemned.

Also I'm not sure what this has to do with scripture canon.

Now read Romans 2, where Paul responds to this passage with "You, therefore, have no excuse, you who pass judgment on someone else, for at whatever point you judge another, you are condemning yourself, because you who pass judgment do the same things. Now we know that God’s judgment against those who do such things is based on truth. So when you, a mere human being, pass judgment on them and yet do the same things, do you think you will escape God’s judgment?"

body:
"ΕΝΑΡΧΗΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹΚΑΙΟΛΟΓΟϹΗΝΠΡΟϹΤΟΝ*ΘΝ*ΚΑΙ***ΘϹ*ΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ**" - Literally, "God (*ΘϹ*) was (ΗΝ) the (Ο) word (ΛΟΓΟϹ)". You object because there's no definite article for ΘϹ. But Mark 1:1 also only has "ΥΙΟΥ*ΘΥ*", so by your logic of "no article=not god but some other thing you haven't specified" he is the son of something else, not god, because there is no definite article here either. That makes no sense of course and is a completely baseless statement, but it's the same argument you're trying to use to disprove John.

Also note that in the next sentence "the word" is called "he" and I don't think it takes a rocket scientist to figure out who it's referring to based on this information.

I think this passage is pretty clear. Your only way out of this one is to say that the gospel of John is inauthentic, or that ΚΑΙ*ΘϹ*ΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ is a later interpolation (this is too small of a passage to conclude either way), or that John was simply wrong (which I find extremely unlikely). In any case this is implied elsewhere throughout the new testament, and I'm not sure why you're so obsessed with it regardless.

> Bahahahaaha. James is as Hebraic as it get in the NT, polytheist, if you're looking for Greek pagan thought look no further than Paul. But even Paul said there's no salvation in idolatry, polytheist, so what could you possibly be hoping for?

Oh that's right, James is the one that barely mentions Jesus. I was thinking of the pastoral epistles when I said Roman. But it's a forgery nonetheless, with the purpose of trying to infiltrate Christianity which was becoming a huge threat to both the Jewish and Roman powers.

Also how is Paul a Greek pagan? As far as I know he was a Pharisee before his conversion, not a Greek pagan.

body:
> How slow are you? John's prologue uses a definite article for God and no article for the logos.

Because the first use of God was in the accusative, which uses an article for names more commonly than the nominative, which is the case of the second use. Also I don't see any use of logos without an article.

> And why does John 17:3 call the father the only true God?

Because he was an incarnation, and also lived as an example that we are to imitate.
body_html:
How slow are you? John's prologue uses a definite article for God and no article for the logos.

Because the first use of God was in the accusative, which uses an article for names more commonly than the nominative, which is the case of the second use. Also I don't see any use of logos without an article.

And why does John 17:3 call the father the only true God?

Because he was an incarnation, and also lived as an example that we are to imitate.

parent.body:
> Abandon the worship of a man, and stop saying that the eternal self sufficient, unfathomable creator of the universe killed Himself in the form of Jesus. It does not stand up to rational logic even slightly.

Then how are we to be absolved?

> Your texts have been halfway forged and rewritten by Paul (who even claimed divine revelation) and the like, and don't exist in their original aramaic.

Paul was not the forger and there is zero evidence that most of the works were originally in aramaic (yes they probably spoke aramaic, but they wanted gentiles to be able to read it too, so they instead wrote in greek). In fact Paul's letters are by a long way the *most* tampered with; the gospels are still mostly intact in their original form as promised. Paul was a good man and a faithful defender of Christ.

body:
No. I'm suggesting that Christians who say that God became a man or had a mortal insignificant (in the scope of the universe) human son, are implying that God is limited. It is insulting and nonsensical to say that God turned himself into a son of his or a man, or had a begotten (literally meaning coitus) son, which He then allowed (He is all powerful) to be slaughtered by the Roman Jews. God is above all of this. His will is instantaneous and inevitable. Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins? He is the unborn and the ever-living. All glory is to God alone! He is well above the partners and sons and polytheism that you ascribe to him by saying Jesus is his relative or equal. He can forgive and he is the forgiver. Not Jesus. Jesus came as a messenger and warner. He came to give glad tidings of heaven and paradise to those who suffer and fight in the way of the truth (solely worshipping God the almighty), and to give heed of a punishment that will cause one to wish for annihilation from existence.

I urge you to take a keen look at your theology, and to examine the chain of information you base your beliefs upon. How has Christianity and its literature been kept through time? How well do you trust the translations from Aramaic or archaic Greek? In Islam (literally Arabic for "acceptance/submission"), the Quran ("that given recitation") is one Quran (no versions), internationally recognized and memorized since the best friend and companion of our Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, ordered it written. Not one syllable may err in its recitation. When you read it, you read the revelation directly. Many verses being with "Qul, " meaning "Say, " because the Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, feared changing a single syllable of what was revealed.

I leave you with my favorite miracle of Mohamed, sallahu alayhi wasalam. He had many miracles, but his greatest one according to him, is the Quran.

It wasn't until the 1920's that a slight blue/red tint to starlight in the night sky (Doppler shift) led scientists to work backwards and conclude that the Universe came out from a single point.

Here is the revelation of God from over 1400 years ago on the tongue of an orphan man born in the middle of the desert:

>أَوَلَمْ يَرَ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًۭا فَفَتَقْنَـٰهُمَا ۖ وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ ٱلْمَآءِ كُلَّ شَىْءٍ حَىٍّ ۖ أَفَلَا يُؤْمِنُونَ

>Do the disbelievers not realize that the heavens and earth were once one mass then We split them apart? And We created from water every living thing. Will they not then believe?

The 30th verse of the 21st chapter of the Quran, the Chapter of the Prophets.

parent.body:
> How slow are you? John's prologue uses a definite article for God and no article for the logos.

Because the first use of God was in the accusative, which uses an article for names more commonly than the nominative, which is the case of the second use. Also I don't see any use of logos without an article.

> And why does John 17:3 call the father the only true God?

Because he was an incarnation, and also lived as an example that we are to imitate.
parent.body_html:
How slow are you? John's prologue uses a definite article for God and no article for the logos.

Because the first use of God was in the accusative, which uses an article for names more commonly than the nominative, which is the case of the second use. Also I don't see any use of logos without an article.

And why does John 17:3 call the father the only true God?

Because he was an incarnation, and also lived as an example that we are to imitate.

body:
> literally, legalistically

Wrong.

But you have neglected the more important matters of the law—justice, mercy and faithfulness. You should have practiced the latter, without neglecting the former. You blind guides! You strain out a gnat but swallow a camel.

> Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind.’ This is the first and greatest commandment. And the second is like it: ‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’ All the Law and the Prophets hang on these two commandments.

Matthew 5 declares he came to fulfill the law and not abolish it, and then proceeds to preach the spirit of the law as opposed to the letter of it, which draws from the second quote I listed. Nothing like the Pharisees' ridiculous legalism.

body:
> It is also the reason you might eat pork (Paul said the old testament was annulled and that every food is pure).

I actually don't recall Paul saying that, though he did talk about the law as a whole. The most frequently cited about meats is actually from Jesus, where he says it is not what goes into a man's mouth that makes him unclean, but what comes out of it. Some people object since the context was about washing hands, but the same principle should still apply, and it also says he declared all foods clean unless you think that was a later addition. There was also a dream Peter had in Acts but there is controversy over whether it is about food or gentile converts (or both). Nevertheless it is more or less implied by the overarching theme of following the spirit of the law rather than the legalistic literalist hypocrisy of mainstream judaism at the time.

Also to note about Paul, the other believers express a positive view of him throughout Acts, including the ones who were with Jesus for his entire ministry. Of course they could have been deceived by him too but I don't find that very likely. And his teachings seem to be almost an exact reiteration of Jesus.

> Why couldn't he do anything on his own?

He *could* just by speaking, and if you think he couldn't you obviously aren't familiar with any of the gospels.

> Who did he plead with? Why wasn't his words his own? Why wasn't his teachings his own? Why choose him? Who found him worthy? Why was it required? Who granted him life? Why didn't he possess it intrinsically? Who granted him authority? Why didn't he possess it intrinsically? Why is going to hand back the kingdom when God's will is according? To whom? Again, he led by example, and was also an incarnation.

body:
> It is insulting and nonsensical to say that God turned himself into a son of his or a man, or had a begotten (literally meaning coitus) son, which He then allowed (He is all powerful) to be slaughtered by the Roman Jews.

It's a gift. In fact some think the whole reason we were made to fall in the first place was so that we could receive it.

> Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins?

Because he is also committed to justice, and it's what makes the gift so perfect.

> I urge you to take a keen look at your theology, and to examine the chain of information you base your beliefs upon. How has Christianity and its literature been kept through time? How well do you trust the translations from Aramaic or archaic Greek?

It's hebrew and koine greek. There are only a few small passages in aramaic. But I do know the gospels are mostly uncorrupted, and where mistakes do occur it doesn't change the meaning. This is not the case in the epistles and other writings, but it is in all the gosepls, which tells me the promise of preservation has been upheld.

> In Islam (literally Arabic for "acceptance/submission"), the Quran ("that given recitation") is one Quran (no versions), internationally recognized and memorized since the best friend and companion of our Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, ordered it written. Not one syllable may err in its recitation. When you read it, you read the revelation directly. Many verses being with "Qul, " meaning "Say, " because the Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, feared changing a single syllable of what was revealed.

You can't tell me that syllables and minor mistakes never occurred in transmission. Both the old and new testaments have variants, and so does the Quran. Not to mention it teaches a good number of evil things.

> أَوَلَمْ يَرَ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًۭا فَفَتَقْنَـٰهُمَا ۖ وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ ٱلْمَآءِ كُلَّ شَىْءٍ حَىٍّ ۖ أَفَلَا يُؤْمِنُونَ

That is based on Genesis, not a new revelation.
body_html:
It is insulting and nonsensical to say that God turned himself into a son of his or a man, or had a begotten (literally meaning coitus) son, which He then allowed (He is all powerful) to be slaughtered by the Roman Jews.

It's a gift. In fact some think the whole reason we were made to fall in the first place was so that we could receive it.

Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins?

Because he is also committed to justice, and it's what makes the gift so perfect.

I urge you to take a keen look at your theology, and to examine the chain of information you base your beliefs upon. How has Christianity and its literature been kept through time? How well do you trust the translations from Aramaic or archaic Greek?

It's hebrew and koine greek. There are only a few small passages in aramaic. But I do know the gospels are mostly uncorrupted, and where mistakes do occur it doesn't change the meaning. This is not the case in the epistles and other writings, but it is in all the gosepls, which tells me the promise of preservation has been upheld.

In Islam (literally Arabic for "acceptance/submission"), the Quran ("that given recitation") is one Quran (no versions), internationally recognized and memorized since the best friend and companion of our Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, ordered it written. Not one syllable may err in its recitation. When you read it, you read the revelation directly. Many verses being with "Qul, " meaning "Say, " because the Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, feared changing a single syllable of what was revealed.

You can't tell me that syllables and minor mistakes never occurred in transmission. Both the old and new testaments have variants, and so does the Quran. Not to mention it teaches a good number of evil things.

أَوَلَمْ يَرَ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًۭا فَفَتَقْنَـٰهُمَا ۖ وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ ٱلْمَآءِ كُلَّ شَىْءٍ حَىٍّ ۖ أَفَلَا يُؤْمِنُونَ

That is based on Genesis, not a new revelation.

parent.body:
No. I'm suggesting that Christians who say that God became a man or had a mortal insignificant (in the scope of the universe) human son, are implying that God is limited. It is insulting and nonsensical to say that God turned himself into a son of his or a man, or had a begotten (literally meaning coitus) son, which He then allowed (He is all powerful) to be slaughtered by the Roman Jews. God is above all of this. His will is instantaneous and inevitable. Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins? He is the unborn and the ever-living. All glory is to God alone! He is well above the partners and sons and polytheism that you ascribe to him by saying Jesus is his relative or equal. He can forgive and he is the forgiver. Not Jesus. Jesus came as a messenger and warner. He came to give glad tidings of heaven and paradise to those who suffer and fight in the way of the truth (solely worshipping God the almighty), and to give heed of a punishment that will cause one to wish for annihilation from existence.

I urge you to take a keen look at your theology, and to examine the chain of information you base your beliefs upon. How has Christianity and its literature been kept through time? How well do you trust the translations from Aramaic or archaic Greek? In Islam (literally Arabic for "acceptance/submission"), the Quran ("that given recitation") is one Quran (no versions), internationally recognized and memorized since the best friend and companion of our Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, ordered it written. Not one syllable may err in its recitation. When you read it, you read the revelation directly. Many verses being with "Qul, " meaning "Say, " because the Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, feared changing a single syllable of what was revealed.

I leave you with my favorite miracle of Mohamed, sallahu alayhi wasalam. He had many miracles, but his greatest one according to him, is the Quran.

It wasn't until the 1920's that a slight blue/red tint to starlight in the night sky (Doppler shift) led scientists to work backwards and conclude that the Universe came out from a single point.

Here is the revelation of God from over 1400 years ago on the tongue of an orphan man born in the middle of the desert:

>أَوَلَمْ يَرَ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًۭا فَفَتَقْنَـٰهُمَا ۖ وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ ٱلْمَآءِ كُلَّ شَىْءٍ حَىٍّ ۖ أَفَلَا يُؤْمِنُونَ

>Do the disbelievers not realize that the heavens and earth were once one mass then We split them apart? And We created from water every living thing. Will they not then believe?

The 30th verse of the 21st chapter of the Quran, the Chapter of the Prophets.

body:
>Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins?

>Because he is also committed to justice, and it's what makes the gift so perfect.

That doesn't make any sense. God has absolute authority, control, and knowledge over everything that has or ever will exist. He does not need causality. He does not need to have something within this creation happen for something else to happen. His will is executed perfectly at all times. Nothing will ever or has ever happened except by His allowance and predestiny. Jesus, whether or not he is a form of God - polytheism by definition, did not need to die to give God permission to forgive you for your sins. God could dissolve Satan instantly right now if He wanted to. God could transmute this existence into nonexistence instantly if he wanted to. To say that a man or God had to die to forgive your sins is blasphemy. It explicitly limits the abilities and omnipotence of the one true God. 

This misunderstanding is so serious that a final Prophet had to come to teach all people the religion of Christ, which is simply submission to the will of God, and the sole worship of Him alone. Mohamed sallahu alayhi wasalam came to all of mankind, not just the lost sheep (non Juden) of the Israelites (Europeans).

This is not the case in the epistles and other writings, but it is in all the gosepls, which tells me the promise of preservation has been upheld.

In Islam (literally Arabic for "acceptance/submission"), the Quran ("that given recitation") is one Quran (no versions), internationally recognized and memorized since the best friend and companion of our Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, ordered it written. Not one syllable may err in its recitation. When you read it, you read the revelation directly. Many verses being with "Qul, " meaning "Say, " because the Prophet, sallahu alayhi wasalam, feared changing a single syllable of what was revealed.

You can't tell me that syllables and minor mistakes never occurred in transmission. Both the old and new testaments have variants, and so does the Quran. Not to mention it teaches a good number of evil things.

أَوَلَمْ يَرَ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱلسَّمَـٰوَٰتِ وَٱلْأَرْضَ كَانَتَا رَتْقًۭا فَفَتَقْنَـٰهُمَا ۖ وَجَعَلْنَا مِنَ ٱلْمَآءِ كُلَّ شَىْءٍ حَىٍّ ۖ أَفَلَا يُؤْمِنُونَ

That is based on Genesis, not a new revelation.

>Why does he need a man or a Prophet or a Messiah or "Himself" to die to be able to instantly forgive your sins?

>Because he is also committed to justice, and it's what makes the gift so perfect.

That doesn't make any sense. God has absolute authority, control, and knowledge over everything that has or ever will exist. He does not need causality. He does not need to have something within this creation happen for something else to happen. His will is executed perfectly at all times. Nothing will ever or has ever happened except by His allowance and predestiny. Jesus, whether or not he is a form of God - polytheism by definition, did not need to die to give God permission to forgive you for your sins. God could dissolve Satan instantly right now if He wanted to. God could transmute this existence into nonexistence instantly if he wanted to. To say that a man or God had to die to forgive your sins is blasphemy. It explicitly limits the abilities and omnipotence of the one true God. 

This misunderstanding is so serious that a final Prophet had to come to teach all people the religion of Christ, which is simply submission to the will of God, and the sole worship of Him alone. Mohamed sallahu alayhi wasalam came to all of mankind, not just the lost sheep (non Juden) of the Israelites (Europeans).

body: > And God said, “Let there be a vault between the waters to separate water from water.” **So God made the vault and separated the water under the vault from the water above it**. And it was so. God called the vault “sky.” And there was evening, and there was morning, the second day. And God said, **“Let the water under the sky be gathered to one place, and let dry ground appear.”** And it was so. God called the dry ground “land,” and the gathered waters he called “seas.” And God saw that it was good.

body:
This is describing how the Earth was constructed with the two waters separated. 

The Quran is rather describing how God made the beginning of the existence of the universe out of a single point ("a single mass"), and then cleft it asunder. The word used for the cleaving is the same word that is used for when a piece of worn clothing bursts at the seams. This is what happened before God made the Earth as described in Genesis. This is where the matter came from.

This is exactly what basic 20th century science shows. If you look at stars, and know their color barely tints blue or red if they are moving towards or away from you (at thousands of miles per second), you quickly realize that the entire heavens (including the Earth) came from a single point: a big bursting, an explosion.

This does not conflict with the account of genesis, it merely precedes it by a time. The existence was made first so that the Earth could be formed within it.

body:
>He does not need to have something within this creation happen for something else to happen.

>But what if he wants to?

And what if your wrong? Would you rather come to your maker saying 

>"Oh my Lord, I could not believe that you became a mortal man and allowed yourself to be killed to forgive my sins. I know you are greater than all things. Forgive me." 

or 

>"My Lord, I took Jesus as an object of worship besides You, when Jesus said to me 'Your Lord is eschad [Hebrew - singular]', I still made You into a trinity, three. I was wrong to believe that you became a person on Earth who was then killed so that I could be forgiven for my transgressions against You (after You died???)."

I will stick with a chance of being mistaken in the first way. But to each their own. God's mercy is infinite. I think you understand my position, and I understand yours, so there is no need to go on.

Why have loyalty to an entity and activity that throws your generation into meaningless wars, allows you to be further subjugated by the financial system by means of debt and usury, taxes you incessantly, tells you you can't do anything without proper licensing, that sells you out to oppressive foreign interests, de-values your savings by planned inflation,  enforces lockdowns, Kills your babies, etc...

What does your earthly government do right now that makes you want to participate in what it is doing?  Do you suppose it upholds Christian values?  Where? When has this ever been done?

Do you suppose your government - specifically the USA - was founded on Christianity?  Where in the constitution does it mention anything about it?

Why do you vote?  To be an accomplice in what ever pyschopath politician enacts and enforces?  Do you enjoy imposing your will on others?

A Christian only serves one and that is God.  You cannot serve both your government and God.

body:
>So why is that word used in Genesis 1?

Because it comes from the root meaning might or power, there is no Hebrew word synonymous with deity, and both human beings and angels are called both elohim and el.
body_html:
So why is that word used in Genesis 1?

Because it comes from the root meaning might or power, there is no Hebrew word synonymous with deity, and both human beings and angels are called both elohim and el.

parent.body:
> And elohim doesn't even mean deity, idol worshipper, but comes from the root meaning might or power.

So why is that word used in Genesis 1?

> Answer the questions now; who did Jesus pray to, plead with and call his God? Who found him worthy? Who will he submit to? Stop deflecting now and answer.

I explained multiple times, he was an incarnation and led by example. He *never* made the excuse for hypocrisy "do as I say, not as I do". It was always "do as I do".
parent.body_html:
And elohim doesn't even mean deity, idol worshipper, but comes from the root meaning might or power.

So why is that word used in Genesis 1?

Answer the questions now; who did Jesus pray to, plead with and call his God? Who found him worthy? Who will he submit to? Stop deflecting now and answer.

I explained multiple times, he was an incarnation and led by example. He never made the excuse for hypocrisy "do as I say, not as I do". It was always "do as I do".
